title.narrative: 2.2: QUALITY SOCIAL SERVICE PACKAGES (6-18 YEARS)

description.narrative: 2.2: Improved and quality social service packages (primary, secondary and alternative education, adolescent and sexual and reproductive health, violence prevention, child-friendly justice processes and adolescent participation) are more available to children aged 6â€“18, particularly girls in targeted, deprived areas., which contributes to Access To Justice, Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Equitable Access To Quality Education, Hiv Prevention, Learning Outcomes, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children, Sanitation, Skills Development. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2022, increased proportions of children and adolescents (6-18 years), particularly girls living in deprived areas, have enhanced and equitable uptake of quality social services (primary, secondary and alternative education, adolescent health, violence prevention, child-friendly justice processes and adolescent participation).

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: 2.2: Improved and quality social service packages (primary, secondary and alternative education, adolescent and sexual and reproductive health, violence prevention, child-friendly justice processes and adolescent participation) are more available to children aged 6–18, particularly girls in targeted, deprived areas.

description.narrative: Although the closure of schools on March 23, 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic constrained the implementation of integrated social service packages during the first semester, important results around the provision of key services for children and adolescents were achieved. Approximately 8,366 students (3,816 girls) benefitted from improved learning environments due to the capacitation of 16 trainers and 150 teachers and directors in Huila on student-centred learning and differentiated instruction. UNICEF Angola also supported the Ministry of Social Welfare to develop and launch a hotline, “SOS Criança,” for reporting violence against children that registered 10,318 reports in its first month. | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:28/08/2020
